column3: Clue
The group in an experiment that receives the treatment or intervention being studied.
A proposed explanation for a phenomenon that can be tested through experimentation.
The factor that is measured or observed to see if it is affected by the independent variable.
The process of assigning participants to experimental and control groups by chance.
A procedure in which the researchers, the participants, or both are unaware of who is in the experimental or control groups.
column4: What is blinding (or a blind study)?

column3: The degree to which the results of an experiment can be generalized to other settings, people, and times.
A flaw in the experimental design that allows an outside variable to influence the dependent variable.
The extent to which a cause-and-effect relationship established in a study can be trusted.
The effect on an outcome that occurs when participants' expectations, rather than the treatment itself, influence the result.
A threat to validity that occurs when participants drop out of a study over time.
A research design that compares two groups, one that receives a treatment and one that does not.
An experiment conducted in a controlled environment, such as a laboratory.
A design where all participants are exposed to every treatment or condition, including the control.
An experiment conducted in a real-world setting, not in a lab.
A study that resembles an experiment but lacks random assignment, often due to practical or ethical constraints.
The entire group of individuals that a researcher is interested in studying.
A subset of the population that is selected to participate in the study.
A sampling method where every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected.
A sampling technique where the population is divided into subgroups (strata) and a random sample is taken from each subgroup.
A non-probability sampling method where researchers rely on the ease of reaching potential participants.
Data that is numerical and can be measured.
A statistical test used to compare the means of two groups to see if they are significantly different.
A measure of the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables.
The value that indicates the probability of finding the observed results when the null hypothesis is true, often set at a 0.05 threshold.
A statistical method used to compare the means of three or more groups, with the acronym ANOVA.
The variable that is manipulated or changed by the researcher to observe its effect on another variable.
The process of assigning participants to different experimental groups in a way that each participant has an equal chance of being in any group.
The variable that is measured by the researcher to see if it is affected by the independent variable.
In an experiment, this is the group that does not receive the experimental treatment and is used as a benchmark.
A testable statement about the relationship between two or more variables.
The extent to which the results of a study can be generalized to other situations, people, or times.
The degree to which an experiment is free from flaws, ensuring that the independent variable caused the observed effect.
The phenomenon where participants alter their behavior simply because they know they are being observed.
A threat to internal validity where natural changes in the participants over time (e.g., growing older, getting tired) could affect the results.
A threat to internal validity where an external event occurs during the experiment that could influence the dependent variable.
A simple experiment where two versions (A and B) of a single variable are compared, commonly used for websites and ads.
In this design, different groups of participants are exposed to different experimental conditions.
In this design, the same group of participants is exposed to all of the different experimental conditions.
column4: What is a Within-Subjects (or Repeated Measures) Design?

column3: An experiment that lacks random assignment to treatment groups, often used when randomization is not feasible.
A design that studies two or more independent variables simultaneously, allowing for the examination of their interaction effects.
The consistency or repeatability of a measure; if you measure the same thing multiple times, you get a similar result.
The extent to which a measure accurately captures the concept it is intended to measure.
A scale that asks respondents to rate their agreement with a statement, typically on a 5 or 7-point scale.
An abstract idea or concept being studied, such as 'brand loyalty' or 'customer satisfaction'.
A scale that measures attitudes by asking respondents to rate a concept on a series of bipolar adjective pairs, like 'Good-Bad' or 'Modern-Traditional'.
column4: What is a Semantic Differential Scale?

column3: This test is used to determine if there is a significant difference between the means of two groups.
This test, an acronym for Analysis of Variance, is used to compare the means of three or more groups.
In hypothesis testing, this is the probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as the observed results, assuming the null hypothesis is true.
This type of error occurs when a researcher incorrectly rejects a true null hypothesis (a 'false positive').
column4: What is a Type I Error?

column3: This statistical test is used to determine if there is a significant association between two categorical variables.
